reviewText: I have always been a fan of the classic westerns but was never a big John Wayne fan or even a real Clint Eastwood worshiper. For me the ultimate Western was always Shane, and I measured most westerns by that lofty standard. I grew up watching The Rifleman TV series, which sadly is still not fully represented on DVD (only on the long out of print 6 MPI box sets, which I have), and the Lone Ranger of course.Until westerns started showing up on DVD, I never had many on home video. Then I started getting into the John Ford westerns, starting with The Searchers of course, the best Wayne western he ever did. What attracted me to Ford was the cinematography of course, and the gritty realism of the storytelling. From there I got into the Jimmy Stewart-Anthony Mann westerns, all great collaborations and again more realistic to me than many of the over the top Wayne movies. With Mann, the more noirish element was brought into the Western, with more complex storylines than a simple good guys vs bad guys or Cowboys vs Indians. From there I got into the Sam Peckinpaugh movies, which took that trend toward realism to another level in the 60s.What I had unwittingly skipped or missed was the link between Mann and Peckinpaugh---Budd Boetticher.I never really heard of Budd Boetticher or Randolph Scott for that matter until recently when I started looking for western films like Shane and the Mann films. Scott flew under the radar as a western star since the films he starred in were termed more "B" westerns that played as the first feature before the main attraction. Then I found the Budd Boetticher collection of Ranown films made in a short period of time in the late 50s with Scott as the star and-----NIRVANA! THESE were exactly the type of westerns that appeal to me. Fantastic widescreen color cinematography shot in the Lone Pine area, with the stark craggy landscape almost being a character in the films (with the obvious Ford and Shane influences present in the filming). Realistic and darker storylines, but direct and simple at the same time. Fast paced, a flow of action and dialogue that ropes you in and immerses you in the film. "Bad guys" who were fully fleshed out and complex and interesting characters, not simply cardboard cutouts. And Randolph Scott, the lonesome oftentimes reluctant antihero, whose craggy visage reflected the rocky, simple and stark landscape the films were shot in. How did I ever miss these???That box set collection (http://www.amazon.com/Boetticher-Decision-Buchanan-Lonesome-Comanche/dp/B001ER4CNO/ref) is simply one of the best collections of its kind ever. There are plenty of reviews of it that explain the films better than I can. Simply put, if you are a western film fan, they are essential. Boetticher and Scott made 7 films together, and 5 of them are in that box set. The first one, the fantastic Seven Men From Now, is on an incredible special edition DVD of its own which is a must buy. Both the box set and the Seven Men From Now DVD contain documentary specials about the fascinating maverick director Boetticher and how these films got made. You begin to understand from Boetticher's bullfighter fascination the motivations and outlook he had and why Scott became the symbol of the somewhat lonesome individualism--trying to do the right and just thing, yet morally ambiguous at times as well. The revenge plotline of many of these films would be highly influential to Eastwood and Peckinpaugh later. The dialogue is always tight and spare, the films are fast paced and don't have wasted frames, and the confrontations between Scott and the "villians" in every film are full of tension and taut drama.So naturally after getting those films I went searching for more, basically getting just about any western Scott had ever done, and also to complete the Ranown cycle with the 7th more elusive film, Westbound. This set contains that 7th Boetticher-Scott film, Westbound, shot in 1959, as well as some of Scott's earlier black and white westerns and some of Scott's collaboration with director Andre De'Toth. (As the Amazon description says, this box set contains Badmen's Territory/Trail Street/Return of the Bad Men/Carson City/Westbound). Its too bad they didn't throw in another Scott-De'Toth film, The Bounty Hunter, which aired recently on Encore Westerns (which I recorded of course). The De'Toth films aren't quite as good as the Boetticher Ranown films, but they are also quite good with similar revenge themes and lonely and reluctant hereo themes, and Scott lends a consistency to all these Westerns. These films are from Warner Archives, which means they are spare DVD-Rs, no special features etc. But even so, the transfers are pretty darn good, and lets face it, its the only way to get these films, most of which have never been available on home video before.I have yet to run across a Scott western that was not well made or uninteresting. While his characters don't vary much, its that consistency which lends realism to all his westerns, and its obvious after watching most of these Scott westerns that he is a truly overlooked and highly influential actor that is finally getting his due with these many DVD releases. Start with the Boetticher set, but get this to supplement it. From there, you will want to get the 2 Triple Feature Warner collections of Scott Westerns (Man Behind the Gun/Thunder Over the Plains/Riding Shotgun) and (Fort Worth/Colt 45/Tall Man Riding) which contain more Scott-De'Toth collaborations and are in glorious technicolor also.
summary: FANTASTIC supplement to the Budd Boetticher Collection of Scott Westerns
Title: Randolph Scott: The Warner Archive Classics Collection: (Badman's Territory / Trail Street / Return of the Bad Men / Carson City / Westbound)

reviewText: Not only were these movies entertaining, The quality of the sound and picture was brilliant, Thankyou Warner Bros for releasing these great films, I hope you release plenty more westerns in the future.
Title: Randolph Scott: The Warner Archive Classics Collection: (Badman's Territory / Trail Street / Return of the Bad Men / Carson City / Westbound)

reviewText: Very enjoyable old classic movies.  Randolph Scott is a great actor .  I would recommend to anyone who likes the old westerns.
Title: Randolph Scott: The Warner Archive Classics Collection: (Badman's Territory / Trail Street / Return of the Bad Men / Carson City / Westbound)

reviewText: A great selection of Randolph Scott movies. Even Though these movies have not been remastered they are in  pretty good shape for there age. My favourite of course is Carson City.Scott was my favorite western hero.Ken BarrettMooroolbark VicAustralia
summary: Randolph  Scott : The Warner Archive Classics Collection
Title: Randolph Scott: The Warner Archive Classics Collection: (Badman's Territory / Trail Street / Return of the Bad Men / Carson City / Westbound)

reviewText: FIVE GREAT RANDOLPH SCOTT WESTERNS ON INDIVIDUAL DISKS, THREE IN BLACK AND WHITE AND TWO IN COLOR, AND ALL FIVE FULL OF BELIEVABLE ACTION. FOLLOW SCOTT INTO "BADMAN'S TERRITORY" WHERE HE MEETS MANY LEGENDARY OUTLAWS WHILE FIGHTING A POWER HUNGRY U.S. MARSHALL. STAND BY HIM IN "TRAIL STREET" WHEN HE TRIES TO BALANCE THE CONFLICTING DEMANDS OF SALOON OWNERS, SHOPKEEPERS, CATTLEMEN AND HOMESTEADERS. IN "RETURN OF THE BAD MEN" RANDOLF RELUCTANTLY ACCEPTS THE ROLE OF LAWMAN IN THE NEWLY FORMED OKLAHOMA TERRITORY. THEN ITS OFF TO "CARSON CITY" TO BUILD A RAILROAD TO CONNECT THE GOLD RICH MINES OF THE AREA TO THE SOUTHERN PACIFIC RAILROAD AND BYPASS THE BANDITS WHO HAVE PLAGUED THE MINE OWNERS. FINALLY, GO "WESTBOUND" WITH HIM TO ENSURE THAT CALIFORNIA GOLD REACHES THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT DURING THE  CIVIL WAR. THREE OF THESE FILMS FEATURE GEORGE "GABBY" HAYES AND INSTEAD OF BEING THE BUMBLING, "COMICAL" SIDEKICK COMMON TO EARLY WESTERNS IS INSTEAD CAST IN A STRONG, SUPPORTING ROLE. POP THE POPCORN, TURN DOWN THE LIGHTS AND ENJOY FIVE SOLID ENTERTAINING RANDOLPH SCOTT CLASSICS.
Title: Randolph Scott: The Warner Archive Classics Collection: (Badman's Territory / Trail Street / Return of the Bad Men / Carson City / Westbound)

reviewText: Finally Warner Archive re-released this box set into one. There are five disks and it's all in one case and not in five separate cases. It's the same asRandolph Scott: The Warner Archive Classics Collection (Badman's Territory / Trail Street / Return of the Bad Men / Carson City / Westbound), but this has only one case with five for the older version. So I would recommend getting this so you can save space and it would save you money from buying the movies separate. The quality of the movies are great with "Badman's Territory" kind of grainy some times, but is worth watching. There isn't much features except for a few Trailers and there isn't any subtitles or other languages then English.-Badman's Territory (1946/b&w;/Full Frame/98mins)Scott, George "Gabby" Hays, Ann Richards, Ray Collins, James Warren; Directed by Tim Whelan-Trail Street (1947/b&w;/Full frame/84mins)Scott, Robert Ryan, Anne Jeffreys, George "Gabby" Hays, Steve Brodie; Directed by Ray Enright-Return of the Bad Men (1948/b&w;/ Full frame/90mins)Scott, Robert Ryan, Anne Jeffreys, George "Gabby" Hays, Jacqueline White, Steve Brodie; Directed by Ray Enright-Carson City (1952/color/Full frame/87mins)Scott, Lucille Norman, Raymond Massey, Richard Webb, Larry Keating; Directed by Andre De Toth-Westbound (1958/color/Widescreen/72mins)Scott, Virginia Mayo, Karen Steele, Michael Dante, Andrew Duggan; Directed by Budd BoetticherOverall this is a awesome set of Randolph Scott Westerns and I would recommend this to anyone interested in Westerns or fans of these stars in these films.
summary: Randolph Scott: The Warner Archive Classics Collection (2013 re-release)
Title: Randolph Scott: The Warner Archive Classics Collection: (Badman's Territory / Trail Street / Return of the Bad Men / Carson City / Westbound)

reviewText: I can't add much to C.R.s review other than, CARSON CITY and WESTBOUND are in color and they are all fullscreen, except WESTBOUND its widescreen. Hopefully now we can look forward to another set with THE NEVADAN,CORONER CREEK,WESTERN UNION,BELLE OF THE YUKON and others.
summary: ANOTHER TOP NOTCH SET OF SCOTT FILMS
Title: Randolph Scott: The Warner Archive Classics Collection: (Badman's Territory / Trail Street / Return of the Bad Men / Carson City / Westbound)
